trans-unit.source: Role-based access control in the Microsoft Azure portal
trans-unit.target: Role-based access control in the Microsoft Azure portal

trans-unit.source: Describes how role based access control works and how to set it up
trans-unit.target: Describes how role based access control works and how to set it up

trans-unit.source: We’ve added support for role-based access control (RBAC) in the Microsoft Azure portal to help organizations meet their access management requirements simply and precisely.
trans-unit.target: We’ve added support for role-based access control (RBAC) in the Microsoft Azure portal to help organizations meet their access management requirements simply and precisely.

trans-unit.source: The <linkText>blog post</linkText><title></title> will give you a quick introduction of the feature and get you started.
trans-unit.target: The <linkText>blog post</linkText><title></title> will give you a quick introduction of the feature and get you started.

trans-unit.source: This topic describes the concepts in detail and covers additional use cases.
trans-unit.target: This topic describes the concepts in detail and covers additional use cases.

trans-unit.source: Every Azure subscription is associated with an Azure Active Directory.
trans-unit.target: Every Azure subscription is associated with an Azure Active Directory.

trans-unit.source: Users and services that access resources of the subscription using the Microsoft Azure Management Portal or Azure Resource Manager API first need to authenticate with that Azure Active Directory.
trans-unit.target: Users and services that access resources of the subscription using the Microsoft Azure Management Portal or Azure Resource Manager API first need to authenticate with that Azure Active Directory.

trans-unit.source: Azure role-based access control allows you to grant appropriate access to Azure AD users, groups, and services, by assigning roles to them on a subscription or resource group or individual resource level.
trans-unit.target: Azure role-based access control allows you to grant appropriate access to Azure AD users, groups, and services, by assigning roles to them on a subscription or resource group or individual resource level.

trans-unit.source: The assigned role defines the level of access that the users, groups, or services have on the Azure resource.
trans-unit.target: The assigned role defines the level of access that the users, groups, or services have on the Azure resource.

trans-unit.source: A role is a collection of actions that can be performed on Azure resources.
trans-unit.target: A role is a collection of actions that can be performed on Azure resources.

trans-unit.source: A user or a service is allowed to perform an action on an Azure resource if they have been assigned a role that contains that action.
trans-unit.target: A user or a service is allowed to perform an action on an Azure resource if they have been assigned a role that contains that action.

trans-unit.source: For a list of built-in roles and their actions and not actions properties, see Built-in roles.
trans-unit.target: For a list of built-in roles and their actions and not actions properties, see Built-in roles.

trans-unit.source: Access is granted to Azure AD users and services by assigning the appropriate role to them on an Azure resource.
trans-unit.target: Access is granted to Azure AD users and services by assigning the appropriate role to them on an Azure resource.

trans-unit.source: Roles can be assigned to the following types of Azure AD security principals:
trans-unit.target: Roles can be assigned to the following types of Azure AD security principals:

trans-unit.source: Users: roles can be assigned to organizational users that are in the Azure AD with which the Azure subscription is associated.
trans-unit.target: Users: roles can be assigned to organizational users that are in the Azure AD with which the Azure subscription is associated.

trans-unit.source: Roles can also be assigned to external Microsoft account users (such as joe@outlook.com) by using the Invite action to assign the user to a role in the Azure portal.
trans-unit.target: Roles can also be assigned to external Microsoft account users (such as joe@outlook.com) by using the Invite action to assign the user to a role in the Azure portal.

trans-unit.source: Assigning a role to an external Microsoft account user causes a guest account to be created in the Azure AD for it.
trans-unit.target: Assigning a role to an external Microsoft account user causes a guest account to be created in the Azure AD for it.

trans-unit.source: If this guest account is disabled in the directory, the external user won’t be allowed to access any Azure resource that the user has been granted access to.
trans-unit.target: If this guest account is disabled in the directory, the external user won’t be allowed to access any Azure resource that the user has been granted access to.

trans-unit.source: Groups: roles can be assigned to Azure AD security groups.
trans-unit.target: Groups: roles can be assigned to Azure AD security groups.

trans-unit.source: A user is automatically granted access to a resource if the user becomes a member of a group that has access.
trans-unit.target: A user is automatically granted access to a resource if the user becomes a member of a group that has access.

trans-unit.source: The user also automatically loses access to the resource after getting removed from the group.
trans-unit.target: The user also automatically loses access to the resource after getting removed from the group.

trans-unit.source: Managing access via groups by assigning roles to groups and adding users to those groups is the best practice, instead of assigning roles directly to users.
trans-unit.target: Managing access via groups by assigning roles to groups and adding users to those groups is the best practice, instead of assigning roles directly to users.

trans-unit.source: Azure RBAC does not allow assigning roles to distribution lists.
trans-unit.target: Azure RBAC does not allow assigning roles to distribution lists.

trans-unit.source: The ability to assign roles to groups lets an organization extend its existing access control model from its on-premises directory to the cloud, so security groups that are already established to control access on-premises can be re-used to control access to resources in the Azure portal.
trans-unit.target: The ability to assign roles to groups lets an organization extend its existing access control model from its on-premises directory to the cloud, so security groups that are already established to control access on-premises can be re-used to control access to resources in the Azure portal.

trans-unit.source: For more information about different options for synchronizing users and groups from an on-premises directory, see <linkText>Directory integration</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about different options for synchronizing users and groups from an on-premises directory, see <linkText>Directory integration</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Azure AD Premium also offers a <linkText>delegated group management feature</linkText><title></title> with which the ability to create and manage groups can be delegated to non-administrator users from Azure AD.
trans-unit.target: Azure AD Premium also offers a <linkText>delegated group management feature</linkText><title></title> with which the ability to create and manage groups can be delegated to non-administrator users from Azure AD.

trans-unit.source: Service principals: service identities are represented as service principals in the directory.
trans-unit.target: Service principals: service identities are represented as service principals in the directory.

trans-unit.source: They authenticate with Azure AD and securely communicate with one another.
trans-unit.target: They authenticate with Azure AD and securely communicate with one another.

trans-unit.source: Services can be granted access to Azure resources by assigning roles via the Azure module for Windows PowerShell to the Azure AD service principal representing that service.
trans-unit.target: Services can be granted access to Azure resources by assigning roles via the Azure module for Windows PowerShell to the Azure AD service principal representing that service.

trans-unit.source: Access does not need to be granted to the entire subscription.
trans-unit.target: Access does not need to be granted to the entire subscription.

trans-unit.source: Roles can also be assigned for resource groups as well as for individual resources.
trans-unit.target: Roles can also be assigned for resource groups as well as for individual resources.

trans-unit.source: In Azure RBAC, a resource inherits role assignments from its parent resources.
trans-unit.target: In Azure RBAC, a resource inherits role assignments from its parent resources.

trans-unit.source: So if a user, group, or service is granted access to only a resource group within a subscription, they will be able to access only that resource group and resources within it, and not the other resources groups within the subscription.
trans-unit.target: So if a user, group, or service is granted access to only a resource group within a subscription, they will be able to access only that resource group and resources within it, and not the other resources groups within the subscription.

trans-unit.source: As another example, a security group can be added to the Reader role for a resource group, but be added to the Contributor role for a database within that resource group.
trans-unit.target: As another example, a security group can be added to the Reader role for a resource group, but be added to the Contributor role for a database within that resource group.

trans-unit.source: Subscription administrator and co-admins will continue to have full access to the Azure portals and management APIs.
trans-unit.target: Subscription administrator and co-admins will continue to have full access to the Azure portals and management APIs.

trans-unit.source: In the RBAC model, they are assigned the Owner role at the subscription level.
trans-unit.target: In the RBAC model, they are assigned the Owner role at the subscription level.

trans-unit.source: However, the new RBAC model is supported only by the Azure portal and Azure Resource Manager APIs.
trans-unit.target: However, the new RBAC model is supported only by the Azure portal and Azure Resource Manager APIs.

trans-unit.source: Users and services that are assigned RBAC roles cannot access the Azure Management Portal and the Service Management APIs.
trans-unit.target: Users and services that are assigned RBAC roles cannot access the Azure Management Portal and the Service Management APIs.

trans-unit.source: Adding a user to the Owner role of a subscription in the Azure portal does not make that user a co-administrator of the subscription in the full Azure portal.
trans-unit.target: Adding a user to the Owner role of a subscription in the Azure portal does not make that user a co-administrator of the subscription in the full Azure portal.

trans-unit.source: If you wish to grant access to a user to an Azure Resource that isn’t yet available to be managed via the Azure portal, you should add them to the subscription co-administrators using the Azure Management Portal.
trans-unit.target: If you wish to grant access to a user to an Azure Resource that isn’t yet available to be managed via the Azure portal, you should add them to the subscription co-administrators using the Azure Management Portal.

trans-unit.source: Service Bus and StorSimple are examples of resources that cannot be managed by using RBAC today.
trans-unit.target: Service Bus and StorSimple are examples of resources that cannot be managed by using RBAC today.

trans-unit.source: Role-based access control is supported only for management operations of the Azure resources in Azure portal and Azure Resource Manager APIs.
trans-unit.target: Role-based access control is supported only for management operations of the Azure resources in Azure portal and Azure Resource Manager APIs.

trans-unit.source: Not all data level operations for Azure resources can be authorized via RBAC.
trans-unit.target: Not all data level operations for Azure resources can be authorized via RBAC.

trans-unit.source: For instance, create/read/update/delete of Storage Accounts can be controlled via RBAC, but create/read/update/delete of blobs or tables within the Storage Account cannot yet be controlled via RBAC.
trans-unit.target: For instance, create/read/update/delete of Storage Accounts can be controlled via RBAC, but create/read/update/delete of blobs or tables within the Storage Account cannot yet be controlled via RBAC.

trans-unit.source: Similarly, create/read/update/delete of a SQL DB can be controlled via RBAC but create/read/update/delete of SQL tables within the DB cannot yet be controlled via RBAC.
trans-unit.target: Similarly, create/read/update/delete of a SQL DB can be controlled via RBAC but create/read/update/delete of SQL tables within the DB cannot yet be controlled via RBAC.

trans-unit.source: Let’s take a look at an example of how a resource owner in an organization can manage access.
trans-unit.target: Let’s take a look at an example of how a resource owner in an organization can manage access.

trans-unit.source: In this scenario, you have multiple people working on a variety of test and production projects that are built using Azure resources.
trans-unit.target: In this scenario, you have multiple people working on a variety of test and production projects that are built using Azure resources.

trans-unit.source: You want to follow best practices for granting access.
trans-unit.target: You want to follow best practices for granting access.

trans-unit.source: Users should have access to all resources that they need, but no additional access.
trans-unit.target: Users should have access to all resources that they need, but no additional access.

trans-unit.source: You want to re-use all the investments you have made in processes and tooling to use security groups that are mastered in an on-premises Active Directory.
trans-unit.target: You want to re-use all the investments you have made in processes and tooling to use security groups that are mastered in an on-premises Active Directory.

trans-unit.source: These sections cover how you set up access to these resources:
trans-unit.target: These sections cover how you set up access to these resources:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Add access</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Add access</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Remove access</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Remove access</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Add or remove access for external user</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Add or remove access for external user</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: Here is a summary of the access requirements and how they are set up in Azure.
trans-unit.target: Here is a summary of the access requirements and how they are set up in Azure.

trans-unit.source: User/Group
trans-unit.target: User/Group

trans-unit.source: Access requirement
trans-unit.target: Access requirement

trans-unit.source: role and scope for access
trans-unit.target: role and scope for access

trans-unit.source: All of Jill Santos’ team
trans-unit.target: All of Jill Santos’ team

trans-unit.source: Read all Azure resources
trans-unit.target: Read all Azure resources

trans-unit.source: Add the AD group that represents Jill Santos’ team to Reader role for the Azure subscription
trans-unit.target: Add the AD group that represents Jill Santos’ team to Reader role for the Azure subscription

trans-unit.source: All of Jill Santos’ team
trans-unit.target: All of Jill Santos’ team

trans-unit.source: Create and manage all resources in the Test resource group
trans-unit.target: Create and manage all resources in the Test resource group

trans-unit.source: Add the AD group that represents Jill Santos’ team to Contributor role for the Test resource group
trans-unit.target: Add the AD group that represents Jill Santos’ team to Contributor role for the Test resource group

trans-unit.source: Brock
trans-unit.target: Brock

trans-unit.source: Create and manage all resources in the Prod resource group
trans-unit.target: Create and manage all resources in the Prod resource group

trans-unit.source: Add Brock to Contributor role for the Prod resource group
trans-unit.target: Add Brock to Contributor role for the Prod resource group

trans-unit.source: First, let’s add Read access for all resources of the subscription.
trans-unit.target: First, let’s add Read access for all resources of the subscription.

trans-unit.source: Click Browse > Everything > Subscriptions.
trans-unit.target: Click Browse > Everything > Subscriptions.

trans-unit.source: Click name of your subscription * > Reader > Add*.
trans-unit.target: Click name of your subscription * > Reader > Add*.

trans-unit.source: From the list of users and groups, select or type the name of the Active Directory group.
trans-unit.target: From the list of users and groups, select or type the name of the Active Directory group.

trans-unit.source: Then add the same team to the Contributor role of the Test resource group.
trans-unit.target: Then add the same team to the Contributor role of the Test resource group.

trans-unit.source: Click the resource group to open its property blade.
trans-unit.target: Click the resource group to open its property blade.

trans-unit.source: Under Roles, click Contributor > Add and type the name of the team.
trans-unit.target: Under Roles, click Contributor > Add and type the name of the team.

trans-unit.source: To add Brock to the Contributor role of the Prod resource group, click the resource group click Contributor > Add and type Brock’s name.
trans-unit.target: To add Brock to the Contributor role of the Prod resource group, click the resource group click Contributor > Add and type Brock’s name.

trans-unit.source: Role assignments can also be managed by using the Microsoft Azure module for Windows PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: Role assignments can also be managed by using the Microsoft Azure module for Windows PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: Here is an example of adding Brock's account by using the New-AzureRoleAssignment cmdlet rather than the portal:
trans-unit.target: Here is an example of adding Brock's account by using the New-AzureRoleAssignment cmdlet rather than the portal:

trans-unit.source: For more information about using Windows PowerShell to add and remove access, see <linkText>Managing role-based access control with Windows PowerShell</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about using Windows PowerShell to add and remove access, see <linkText>Managing role-based access control with Windows PowerShell</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: You can also remove assignments easily.
trans-unit.target: You can also remove assignments easily.

trans-unit.source: Let’s say you want to remove a user named Brad Adams from the Reader role for a resource group named TestDB.
trans-unit.target: Let’s say you want to remove a user named Brad Adams from the Reader role for a resource group named TestDB.

trans-unit.source: Open the resource group blade, click Reader > Brad Adams > Remove.
trans-unit.target: Open the resource group blade, click Reader > Brad Adams > Remove.

trans-unit.source: Here is an example of how to remove Brad Adams by using the Remove-AzureRoleAssignment cmdlet:
trans-unit.target: Here is an example of how to remove Brad Adams by using the Remove-AzureRoleAssignment cmdlet:

trans-unit.source: The Configure tab of a directory includes options to control access for external users.
trans-unit.target: The Configure tab of a directory includes options to control access for external users.

trans-unit.source: These options can be changed only in the UI (there is no Windows PowerShell or API method) in the full Azure portal by a directory global administrator.
trans-unit.target: These options can be changed only in the UI (there is no Windows PowerShell or API method) in the full Azure portal by a directory global administrator.

trans-unit.source: To open the Configure tab in the Azure portal, click Active Directory, and then click the name of the directory.
trans-unit.target: To open the Configure tab in the Azure portal, click Active Directory, and then click the name of the directory.

trans-unit.source: Then you can edit the options to control access for external users.
trans-unit.target: Then you can edit the options to control access for external users.

trans-unit.source: By default, guests cannot enumerate the contents of the directory, so they do not see any users or groups in the Member List.
trans-unit.target: By default, guests cannot enumerate the contents of the directory, so they do not see any users or groups in the Member List.

trans-unit.source: They can search for a user by typing the user's full email address, and then grant access.
trans-unit.target: They can search for a user by typing the user's full email address, and then grant access.

trans-unit.source: The set of default restrictions for guests are:
trans-unit.target: The set of default restrictions for guests are:

trans-unit.source: They cannot enumerate users and groups in the directory.
trans-unit.target: They cannot enumerate users and groups in the directory.

trans-unit.source: They can see limited details of a user if they know the user's email address.
trans-unit.target: They can see limited details of a user if they know the user's email address.

trans-unit.source: They can see limited details of a group when they know the group name.
trans-unit.target: They can see limited details of a group when they know the group name.

trans-unit.source: The ability for guests to see limited details of a user or group allows them to invite other people and see some details of people with whom they are collaborating.
trans-unit.target: The ability for guests to see limited details of a user or group allows them to invite other people and see some details of people with whom they are collaborating.

trans-unit.source: Let’s step through the process to add access for an external user.
trans-unit.target: Let’s step through the process to add access for an external user.

trans-unit.source: We’ll add an external user to the same Reader role for TestDB resource group so that user can help debug an error.
trans-unit.target: We’ll add an external user to the same Reader role for TestDB resource group so that user can help debug an error.

trans-unit.source: Open the resource group blade, click Reader > Add > Invite and type the email address of the user you want to add.
trans-unit.target: Open the resource group blade, click Reader > Add > Invite and type the email address of the user you want to add.

trans-unit.source: When you add an external user, a guest is created in the directory.
trans-unit.target: When you add an external user, a guest is created in the directory.

trans-unit.source: Thereafter, that guest can be added to a group or removed from a group, or you can add or remove it individually from a role just like you would for any other directory users.
trans-unit.target: Thereafter, that guest can be added to a group or removed from a group, or you can add or remove it individually from a role just like you would for any other directory users.

trans-unit.source: You can also remove a guest from any role, just as you would remove any user.
trans-unit.target: You can also remove a guest from any role, just as you would remove any user.

trans-unit.source: Removing the guest from a role on a resource does not remove the guest from the directory.
trans-unit.target: Removing the guest from a role on a resource does not remove the guest from the directory.

trans-unit.source: Changes to role assignments are logged in the <linkText>Audit logs</linkText><title></title>, similar to other events.
trans-unit.target: Changes to role assignments are logged in the <linkText>Audit logs</linkText><title></title>, similar to other events.

trans-unit.source: The log of role assignment changes can be retrieved using <linkText>Azure PowerShell</linkText><title></title> or the <linkText>Azure Resource Manager REST API</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: The log of role assignment changes can be retrieved using <linkText>Azure PowerShell</linkText><title></title> or the <linkText>Azure Resource Manager REST API</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: For example, to retrieve the list of role assignment changes for an entire subscription, run the following two cmdlets with Azure PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: For example, to retrieve the list of role assignment changes for an entire subscription, run the following two cmdlets with Azure PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: The first one switches to Azure Resource Manager mode.
trans-unit.target: The first one switches to Azure Resource Manager mode.

trans-unit.source: Switch-AzureMode -name AzureResourceManager
trans-unit.target: Switch-AzureMode -name AzureResourceManager

trans-unit.source: Get-AzureSubscriptionIdLog –DetailedOutput -StartTime '06-15-15' -EndTime '06-29-15'
trans-unit.target: Get-AzureSubscriptionIdLog –DetailedOutput -StartTime '06-15-15' -EndTime '06-29-15'

trans-unit.source: Role assignment changes are captured in events where the ResourceProviderName is Microsoft.Authorization.
trans-unit.target: Role assignment changes are captured in events where the ResourceProviderName is Microsoft.Authorization.

trans-unit.source: The actual detail of the assignment is captured in the event detail: what principal was assigned, to what role, for what scope.
trans-unit.target: The actual detail of the assignment is captured in the event detail: what principal was assigned, to what role, for what scope.

trans-unit.source: Role assignment changes are visible when browsing audit logs in the portal, but the portal does not show the event detail.
trans-unit.target: Role assignment changes are visible when browsing audit logs in the portal, but the portal does not show the event detail.

trans-unit.source: To view event detail, you must use Azure PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: To view event detail, you must use Azure PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: Here's an example of an event detail for a role assignment change:
trans-unit.target: Here's an example of an event detail for a role assignment change:

trans-unit.source: The information in the event is interpreted as follows:
trans-unit.target: The information in the event is interpreted as follows:

trans-unit.source: Field
trans-unit.target: Field

trans-unit.source: Value
trans-unit.target: Value

trans-unit.source: Details
trans-unit.target: Details

trans-unit.source: Caller
trans-unit.target: Caller

trans-unit.source: William.Hennum@contoso.com
trans-unit.target: William.Hennum@contoso.com

trans-unit.source: The principal that made the role assignment.
trans-unit.target: The principal that made the role assignment.

trans-unit.source: The principal could be a user, group, or service principal.
trans-unit.target: The principal could be a user, group, or service principal.

trans-unit.source: HttpRequest: Method
trans-unit.target: HttpRequest: Method

trans-unit.source: PUT
trans-unit.target: PUT

trans-unit.source: The action taken.
trans-unit.target: The action taken.

trans-unit.source: PUT grants an assignment and DELETE removes an assignment.
trans-unit.target: PUT grants an assignment and DELETE removes an assignment.

trans-unit.target: Properties: PrincipalId

trans-unit.target: dda50086-5e3d-4a4b-b8bc-f54771104d89

trans-unit.target: The Object ID of the principal that was assigned to the role.

trans-unit.source: The principal could be a user, group, or service principal.
trans-unit.target: The principal could be a user, group, or service principal.

trans-unit.source: You can determine the name and type of the principal by looking it up in Azure Active Directory using Azure PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: You can determine the name and type of the principal by looking it up in Azure Active Directory using Azure PowerShell.

trans-unit.target: Properties: RoleDefinitionId

trans-unit.target: /subscriptions/ff945b8d-441a-41ef-a9db-7bd5fcc99978/providers/Microsoft.Authorization/roleDefinitions/acdd72a7-3385-48ef-bd42-f606fba81ae7

trans-unit.target: You can determined the display name of the role using Azure PowerShell.

trans-unit.target: /subscriptions/ff945b8d-441a-41ef-a9db-7bd5fcc99978/resourceGroups/Default-Storage-WestUS/providers/Microsoft.ClassicStorage/storageAccounts/authzwaes

trans-unit.source: The resource on which the role assignment was made.
trans-unit.target: The resource on which the role assignment was made.

trans-unit.source: This can be a resource, resource group, or subscription.
trans-unit.target: This can be a resource, resource group, or subscription.

trans-unit.source: If you encounter a problem when you use role based access control feature, see <linkText>Troubleshooting role-based access control</linkText><title></title> for any known issues that may be related to the problem.
trans-unit.target: If you encounter a problem when you use role based access control feature, see <linkText>Troubleshooting role-based access control</linkText><title></title> for any known issues that may be related to the problem.

trans-unit.source: Azure role-based access control comes with the following built-in roles that can be assigned to users, groups, and services.
trans-unit.target: Azure role-based access control comes with the following built-in roles that can be assigned to users, groups, and services.

trans-unit.source: You can’t modify the definition of built-in roles.
trans-unit.target: You can’t modify the definition of built-in roles.

trans-unit.source: In an upcoming release of Azure RBAC, you will be able to define custom roles by composing a set of actions from a list of available actions that can be performed on Azure resources.
trans-unit.target: In an upcoming release of Azure RBAC, you will be able to define custom roles by composing a set of actions from a list of available actions that can be performed on Azure resources.

trans-unit.source: Click the corresponding link to see the actions and not actions properties of a role definition.
trans-unit.target: Click the corresponding link to see the actions and not actions properties of a role definition.

trans-unit.source: The actions property specifies the allowed actions on Azure resources.
trans-unit.target: The actions property specifies the allowed actions on Azure resources.

trans-unit.source: Action strings can use wildcard characters.
trans-unit.target: Action strings can use wildcard characters.

trans-unit.source: The not actions property of a role definition specifies the actions that must be excluded from the allowed actions.
trans-unit.target: The not actions property of a role definition specifies the actions that must be excluded from the allowed actions.

trans-unit.source: Role name
trans-unit.target: Role name

trans-unit.source: Description
trans-unit.target: Description

trans-unit.source: <linkText>API Management Service Contributor</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>API Management Service Contributor</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: Lets you manage API Management service, but not access to them.
trans-unit.target: Lets you manage API Management service, but not access to them.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Application Insights Component Contributor</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Application Insights Component Contributor</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: Lets you manage Application Insights components, but not access to them.
trans-unit.target: Lets you manage Application Insights components, but not access to them.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>BizTalk Contributor</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>BizTalk Contributor</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: Lets you manage BizTalk services, but not access to them.
trans-unit.target: Lets you manage BizTalk services, but not access to them.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>ClearDB MySQL DB Contributor</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>ClearDB MySQL DB Contributor</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: Lets you manage ClearDB MySQL databases, but not access to them.
trans-unit.target: Lets you manage ClearDB MySQL databases, but not access to them.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Contributor</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Contributor</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: Contributors can manage everything except access.
trans-unit.target: Contributors can manage everything except access.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Data Factory Contributor</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Data Factory Contributor</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: Lets you manage data factories, but not access to them.
trans-unit.target: Lets you manage data factories, but not access to them.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Document DB Account Contributor</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Document DB Account Contributor</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: Lets you manage DocumentDB accounts, but not access to them.
trans-unit.target: Lets you manage DocumentDB accounts, but not access to them.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Intelligent Systems Account Contributor</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Intelligent Systems Account Contributor</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: Lets you manage Intelligent Systems accounts, but not access to them.
trans-unit.target: Lets you manage Intelligent Systems accounts, but not access to them.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>NewRelic APM Account Contributor</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>NewRelic APM Account Contributor</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: Lets you manage New Relic Application Performance Management accounts and applications, but not access to them.
trans-unit.target: Lets you manage New Relic Application Performance Management accounts and applications, but not access to them.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Owner</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Owner</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: Owner can manage everything, including access.
trans-unit.target: Owner can manage everything, including access.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Reader</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Reader</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: Readers can view everything, but can't make changes.
trans-unit.target: Readers can view everything, but can't make changes.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Redis Cache Contributor</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Redis Cache Contributor</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: Lets you manage Redis caches, but not access to them.
trans-unit.target: Lets you manage Redis caches, but not access to them.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>SQL DB Contributor</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>SQL DB Contributor</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: Lets you manage SQL databases, but not access to them.
trans-unit.target: Lets you manage SQL databases, but not access to them.

trans-unit.source: Also, you can’t manage their security-related policies or their parent SQL servers.
trans-unit.target: Also, you can’t manage their security-related policies or their parent SQL servers.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>SQL Security Manager</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>SQL Security Manager</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: Lets you manage the security-related policies of SQL servers and databases, but not access to them.
trans-unit.target: Lets you manage the security-related policies of SQL servers and databases, but not access to them.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>SQL Server Contributor</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>SQL Server Contributor</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: Lets you manage SQL servers and databases, but not access to them, and not their security-related policies.
trans-unit.target: Lets you manage SQL servers and databases, but not access to them, and not their security-related policies.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Scheduler Job Collections Contributor</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Scheduler Job Collections Contributor</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: Lets you manage Scheduler job collections, but not access to them.
trans-unit.target: Lets you manage Scheduler job collections, but not access to them.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Search Service Contributor</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Search Service Contributor</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: Lets you manage Search services, but not access to them.
trans-unit.target: Lets you manage Search services, but not access to them.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Storage Account Contributor</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Storage Account Contributor</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: Lets you manage storage accounts, but not access to them.
trans-unit.target: Lets you manage storage accounts, but not access to them.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>User Access Administrator</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>User Access Administrator</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: Lets you manage user access to Azure resources.
trans-unit.target: Lets you manage user access to Azure resources.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Virtual Machine Contributor</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Virtual Machine Contributor</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: Lets you manage virtual machines, but not access to them, and not the virtual network or storage account they’re connected to.
trans-unit.target: Lets you manage virtual machines, but not access to them, and not the virtual network or storage account they’re connected to.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Virtual Network Contributor</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Virtual Network Contributor</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: Lets you manage virtual networks, but not access to them.
trans-unit.target: Lets you manage virtual networks, but not access to them.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Web Plan Contributor</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Web Plan Contributor</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: Lets you manage the web plans for websites, but not access to them.
trans-unit.target: Lets you manage the web plans for websites, but not access to them.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Website Contributor</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Website Contributor</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: Lets you manage websites (not web plans), but not access to them.
trans-unit.target: Lets you manage websites (not web plans), but not access to them.

Microsoft.Web/serverFarms/join/action Join Web Plans
Microsoft.Web/sites/ Create and Manage Web Sites

Microsoft.Authorization//read Read Roles and Role Assignments
Microsoft.Resources/subscriptions/resourceGroups/read Read Resource Groups
Microsoft.Resources/subscriptions/resourceGroups/deployments/ Create and Manage Resource Group Deployments
Microsoft.Insights/alertRules/ Create and Manage Alert Rules
Microsoft.Support/ Create and Manage Support Tickets
